awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:   Automated Pairing and Provisioning
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will be focusing on automatic pairing and provisioning of Internet of Things (IoT) for the Multi-Family-Home (MFH) industry, to help them increase revenue potential by digitizing their apartments. It is estimated that the Smart Home Automation industry will reach $71B by 2018. If installation and setup of IoT devices could be automated and simplified then the MFH industry could roll out Smart Apartments quickly and in large scale. Being able to gather data and insights on buildings could lead to increased revenue from more efficient use of labor and materials and through better management of energy. It also gives them the opportunity to create new revenue streams from software and services targeted at the data output. The MFH industry can also get insights on their entire building portfolio versus a single building and more efficiently manage their entire portfolio. The MFH industry implementing Smart Home Automation technology has huge societal benefits by integrating with smart grids and utility demand response programs. The potential energy savings of 18M Smart Apartments could be hundred thousand gigawatt hours or $7.3B in savings.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project seeks to enable the deployment of a scalable and maintainable infrastructure through the use of mechanisms including automatic pairing, tiered authentication, and network isolation in low cost, resource-constrained Internet of Things (IoT) devices. The problem with existing IoT pairing methods is that they are targeted at Single-Family-Home deployments and the number of nodes that needs to be paired are relatively minimal. However, this is not a scalable model when trying to address the needs of the Multi-Family-Home (MFH) industry. In the multi-family dwelling, the sheer density of nodes creates new problems. The technical challenge that remains for this phase is to ensure that all the devices will easily pair and to differentiate the nodes so that they authenticate and provision to the right apartment in a dense, RF noisy environment. Developing a cost effective, scalable solution for this high-density scenario is a key component to fulfilling the value proposition of mass deployment in the Multi-Family-Home industry. The anticipated result of this project is to solve the issue of pairing large quantities of end nodes and authenticating them appropriately to the correct apartment.

por.por_cntn:
IOTAS Phase II Technical Challenges

Our phase 2 project was to take our very limited lab tested process for automatically pairing smart home devices from our phase 1 grant and show that it could be used in the wild. In the smart home automation space, other than wifi which is generally not available for new construction at the time of pairing, there are two major protocols that dominate the market, Zigbee and Z-Wave. We initially chose Zigbee as our target protocol because it has all the methods we needed for forcibly adding and removing devices from its network.

Zigbee

Initial testing of our Zigbee solution was very successful. We tested on a three hub, nine device setup. We were able to get our hubs to mesh and developed a handshake algorithm so the hubs would successfully take turns pairing devices. We were able to repeatedly show that the hubs were able to identify the correct devices to pair and end up with the correct networks of devices at the conclusion of the process. As we tried to increase the number of hubs and devices we discovered a flaw in our method: we relied on the fact that Zigbee devices, when they power on, are automatically placed into a pairing mode. Unfortunately they time out of that mode after about 30 minutes. As we scaled up our tests we crossed over that 30 minute threshold could no longer pair the devices.

Z-Wave

We initially did not go with Z-Wave because at the time their protocol had no way of adding devices to a network without physically interacting with the device, a non-starter for an automated pairing solution. While we were working on our Zigbee solution, Z-Wave added SmartStart to their solution, which allows one to add a device to the network, provided you know the key for the device. This new feature made it a potentially viable solution again to automate pairing. 

 

When we ran into the Zigbee timeout issue, we decided to investigate whether Z-Wave could be the solution. We were able to reuse most of the work for inter-hub communication and handshaking. Unfortunately, when we started adapting our auto-pairing algorithm we found another issue with the Z-Wave protocol: It does not allow you to remove devices in its network without physically interacting with the device. Our auto-pairing algorithm adds all devices within range then removes devices that it determines are not on the same circuit as the hub. 

 

We worked with one of our manufacturing partners who was willing to modify the firmware on their outlets to have an unused command forcibly remove the device from the network. We were also able to successfully test a couple of their devices with the new firmware. However, we ran into logistical problems that approach, as the manufacturer would have to create a new sku for us and we would have to guarantee purchasing a large quantity of devices. It was also unclear whether the new sku would be able to be certified as it violated part of the Z-Wave protocol.

Tests in Commercial Space

We had lined up a property for our larger scale, 100 unit, commercial test of our auto-pairing solution. We verified that our energy monitoring devices could be wired into and transmit a signal out of the building?s metal, electrical sub-panels to a range of 10 feet, far enough to communicate with where our hub would be installed. We were getting ready to install the energy monitors throughout the building when we discovered our Zigbee timeout issue.



In-Conclusion

We have taken our initial auto-pairing method we developed in phase 1 and shown that it can work in small scale installations, with our hubs automatically coordinating pairing and successfully pairing devices to the correct network in an overlapping radio environment. As we attempted to scale up our solution we found an insurmountable problem in the Zigbee protocol. We attempted to get around this problem by switch protocols but found the Z-Wave protocol also had a problem that could not be overcome. We attempted to work with manufacturers to solve the problems, but in order to get them to move we would have to guarantee to order thousands of units. At this time we do not see a viable way to complete our large scale commercial test with the available hardware and protocols in the market. We will continue to have conversations with our manufacturing partners and try to influence the future direction of the Z-Wave and Zigbee protocols to take into consideration our multi-family home use case, however, at this time, there is no viable path forward to complete the large scale commercialization test for our phase 2 project.
